para.para: Autogenerated identifier classes and identifier objects to Themed Icons registered with .
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the Id field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes â€” either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = CoverageTreeToolBarPrivateThemedIcons.AllTests.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(CoverageTreeToolBarPrivateThemedIcons.AllTests), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<CoverageTreeToolBarPrivateThemedIcons.AllTests>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

para.para: Autogenerated identifier class for the AllTests Themed Icon.
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: For details on Themed Icons and their use, see Remarks on class.

member.name: M:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.ResizeColumn(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Repeats original DevExpress 7.1 ResizeColumn's behavior, but allows resizing of columns while horizontal scrollbar is visible and resizes columns with fixed widths if it's necessary

member.name: M:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.FitColumns
member.summary: If the tree's client width is less than the total columns width, tries to minimize non-fixed columns, if it doesn't help tries to minimize fixed columns Original DevExpress 7.1 implementation doesn't minimize fixed columns

member.name: M:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.CalcColumnBestWidth(DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Columns.TreeListColumn)
member.summary: Calculates column's best width taking into account model's column presenters

member.name: M:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.OnAfterChangeExpanded(DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Nodes.TreeListNode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Recalculates columns' minimum widths after expanding nodes

member.name: M:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.OnUpdateFinished(System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Recalculates columns' minimum widths after the tree model view has been updated

member.name: F:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.myFirstWmPaintMessage
member.summary: Until the tree has been painted for the first time after the creation it can be resized many times before gets its actual size, which leads to multiple calls of FitColumns method. FitColumns method updates the columns widths. So we can restore user's columns widths only after that resize-process has been finished. For that we wait for the first WM_PAINT message, fire ReadyToRestoreColumnStates event and only then start painting.

member.name: F:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.myCurrentColumnWidthsAreTheBest
member.summary: This hack seems to be the only way to update columns' VisibleWidth property according to their widths

member.name: P:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.CoverageTreeView.IsNeededHScrollBar
member.summary: Shows horizontal scrollbar only when the tree's client width is less than the minimum total columns width (ignoring columns fixed widths)

member.name: M:JetBrains.dotCover.CoverageTree.Views.Columns.SymbolCellRenderer.GetToolTipRectangle(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Object,JetBrains.UI.RenderParams)
member.summary: Returns a tooltip rectangle in such a way that the tooltip appears in two cases: if the tree view's client rectangle doesn't contain the hitRect entirely (see ) or if the desired cell's size is greater than its actual size. To achieve the last returns a rectangle the height of which is greater than the hitRect's height.
